eventually used for further analysis of premature mortality burden (as per Eqs. 3
recently constrains the shape of the concentration response function. The IER
estimates RR across a wide range of exposure including ambient air pollution,
household air pollution, active smoking and second-hand smoking. We choose
four diseases, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), ischaemic heart
disease (IHD), stroke and lung cancer (LC). These diseases have direct causal links
. The IER function can be expressed as in Eq. 3
represents the RR for a disease
c constants for each of the diseases. We use the median values of
RR for each disease (for IHD and stroke, age-speci
c values of RR have been
considered), which are provided as a look-up table by a previous study
details about the IER function can be found elsewhere
exposure has been estimated for each decade starting
from 2011 to 2100 using the traditional epidemiological relation
is the baseline mortality for a disease

scenarios has been obtained from the Inter-Sectoral Impact Model Comparison

nes different socioeconomic challenges to mitigation
and adaptation strategies to deal with climate change (more details in

national level for each of the scenarios. For the exposure assessment, the adult (age

rst year of the respective decade. For

population database is required to estimate age-speci
c RR for IHD and stroke. For
We adjust the baseline mortality for each of the diseases as a function of GDP (see
for more information on the non-linear functions). GDP-PPP
(purchasing power parity) is obtained at national level from https://tntcat.iiasa.ac.
countries for two sets of simulations
scenarios. GDP-PPP from both these sets for each decade is averaged. Rate of
change of GDP-PPP for all the decades up to 2100 relative to the baseline period
GDP-PPP (which is considered to be 2010 for India obtained from World Bank)
has been estimated. We assume the GDP at constant prices (USD 2005) to change
at the similar rate as GDP-PPP in future. We obtain GDP at constant price (USD
2011 for all the states from the Reserve Bank of India
Statistics (2014) and regrid it at 0.5° × 0.5° resolution in GIS-based platform. For
evaluating GDP (at constant USD 2005 prices) in future for the 5 SSPs scenarios for
each decade in future, we apply the rate of change of GDP-PPP for that decade
uniformly to each grid. Mathematically, it can be represented as in Eq. 7
is the GDP for a given SSP scenario
projected by IIASA for India in each decade
in future for a SSP scenario
for India in future for a SSP scenario
for India) is applied to GDP at constant prices
to obtain the GDP at constant prices for
each future decade up to 2100. The state-wise estimates are then re-gridded at
0.5° × 0.5° resolution for estimation of baseline mortality using the non-linear
relations for the three diseases (COPD, IHD and stroke), while for LC it is assumed
to remain constant throughout the century
as the LC baseline mortality does not
The uncertainties in the estimates of premature mortality burden estimation
stems from the disagreement in PM
estimated by the CMIP5 models and the
uncertainty in estimation of baseline mortality from GDP using relations from our
. The entire methodology is schematically explained in
. Premature mortality burden in India due to ambient
exposure is projected till the end of the century as discussed above based
on the following underlying assumptions. First, the country-level age-speci
about is applied uniformly for all the grids. Second, the present
day GDP baseline mortality non-linear relation in India is assumed to hold true for
future as well. Third, we consider that the IERs used to estimate RR holds true in
the future decades. RR in the IERs depends only on the PM
not on the composition. Some recent studies have highlighted that RR for cardi-
exposure dominated by biomass burning might not
be the same as of PM
updated in future with inclusion of new cohort studies. Finally, we have not used
emissions projected by the SSP scenarios to estimate future PM
exposure is driven by RCP scenarios only. We also have not
considered air pollution control policies suggested in SSP scenarios
implemented in India in future. Deviation from these assumptions would alter the
estimated premature mortality burden and is a scope of future research.
. The codes used to arrive at the results depicted in this study are
available upon request to the corresponding author (SC).
. Data for CMIP5 models are available at https://esgf-node.llnl.
gov/projects/esgf-llnl/. All SSP data are available at https://tntcat.iiasa.ac.at/SspDb/
about. Gridded population data for all SSPs are
are archived in NASA Langley Research Atmospheric science Data Center. All
